newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan says China anger doesn't change WTO bid.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan says China anger doesn't change WTO bid.

text.p: Taiwan said it remained committed to joining the World Trade Organisation (WTO) despite rival China's indignant comment on Tuesday that it no longer cares whether it joins the global body.
Taipei's application to join the WTO has long been seen as hinging on that of its communist rival. China has said it would not tolerate Taiwan's entry before its own.
"Despite what mainland China says or does, our goal to enter the WTO is clear," an official at cabinet's Board of Foreign Trade said by telephone, asking that his name not be used.
"We are committed to becoming a WTO member and we have stepped up our effort to achieve that goal," the official said.

In Beijing, the official China Daily quoted Wu Jiahuang, director-general of the customs administration's tariffs department, as saying a deeply frustrated China had become "indifferent and doesn't care any more" whether it joins WTO.

Wu compared China's decade-old bid to enter the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the WTO that succeeded GATT to a "sunken boat" and an "ailing tree", the China Daily said in a front-page report.

The Taiwan official said Wu's comments may not represent Beijing's true position, saying it could be a tactic to make the United States, Europe, Japan and Canada rethink their opposition to China's entry for fear it might backfire.
"In our case, no official will make this kind of comments. The entire (Taiwan) administration and parliament are working hand in hand to enter the WTO," the official said.
He declined to say whether Taiwan's WTO application might be further delayed by China's apparent indignation.
"We are doing the best we can, but we have no control over external factors," the official said.
Taiwan applied in 1990 to join GATT as a customs territory under the name of Chinese Taipei.
GATT was replaced by the WTO in January 1995.
Taiwan has made major concessions in recent years in its drive to join the world trade body, allowing more imports, opening domestic markets and dismantling state monopolies.

China, which has seen Taiwan as a renegade province since a civil war split them in 1949, has said it would accept Taiwan's WTO membership as a customs territory -- but only after China itself gets in.
Taiwan has said it wants to join the WTO in 1997.
